Half-Life: Blue Shift feels like a bit of a disappointment after the amazing job Gearbox did with Opposing Force, however it is still a fun game and well worth playing if you like the Half-Life games. 

The main problem with Blue Shift is its length. It only takes about 3 hours to complete which is disappointing considering how Opposing Force was around 8 hours long. It also isn't as unique or original as Opposing Force was.

However despite its flaws the experience is still a fun one. Seeing how Barney Calhoun escaped Black Mesa is interesting if you have played Half-Life 2. Gordon Freeman can be spotted throughout the game which ties it quite nicely with the original. There are some really great puzzle sections as well which really require you to think. The gameplay is very good just like in the other Half-Life games.

Overall, a great game let down mainly by its short length. Worth playing if you are a fan of the franchise.

Having played "Half-Life" and "Half-Life: Opposing Force," I was ready to complete the set and play "Half-Life: Blue Force." When I played it, It felt a bit lacking, but it still managed to have charm. It still maintains what made the other two games work, in terms of it's story and it's engagement.

You play as one of the "red shirts" (or as in this case, blue shirts), aka, a Security Guard, Barney Calhoun. He's one of the lowly security guards in the Black Mesa compound who, surprisingly, proves more badass than most of his own coworkers. Again, for the same reason I enjoyed playing as Gordon Freeman in HL and as Adrian Shepherd in HL:OF, Barney is a character that can get very immersive, owing to his silence. And you never lose control of him in the game, keeping you firmly in his POV.

Most of what I have to say about this game has already been said in my other reviews of HL and HL:OF, so I won't go into too much detail. I liked the continuous level design, giving the feel of exploration, and enough of a story that will keep you invested in the game. I also liked how this game used armor instead of a powered suit, making it easier to maintain by just findining more armor, preventing you from slowing down too much.

But therein lies the problem. Whereas "Opposing Force" had plenty of new stuff, this game feels lacking. You only get a few of the weapons from the first game, and this game is much shorter compared to the first game. I feel this game fell short of it's predecessor by not trying anything new to expand upon the story and setting. I am glad though that there isn't as much platforming as the original, like in HL:OF, which did the same. But the one thing that saved it for me was how they made you feel more involved in the plot, near the climax of the game. But overall, I feel this game could have been so much more.

While this expansion didn't have what "Opposing Force" has to offer, it still manages to work fine on it's own, and it's not terrible. It's enough to keep you invested, but it's kind of a letdown after a good game and a good expansion pack. But if I had to play it again, I'd play it again, soundly.
Short, but if you enjoyed the main Half Life game and want a bit more from a different point of view, give it a shot.

Well this was underwhelming. I'll vote the game down. Why? Because if one buys the Anthology, he won't care about this at all. But if someone checks the individual games, maybe gets a little look into the game, and I hope that can understand this. To be really short: game is too short, quite shallow, less guns, less varied environments - nowhere as good as HL or Opposing Forces.

HL Blue Shift currently stands at 90% positive reviews, while HL and Opposing Forces if I remember well has 96% and 95%  positives, and I have to agree with the trend - the game was fine, but not even as good as HL (This is my third, final review of the anthology - in my book Opposing Forces > Half-Life > Blue Shift, simply based amount the fun I had while playing)
The game features a really awesome physics based puzzle (barrels in coolant), had a fun part shooting gas cannisters' top to make them shoot at a door, and a barrel-detonator puzzle  which is really questionable in my opinion. 
Otherwise this game feels like a well-written, longer trailer for Half-Life. Alien contact's majority are headcrabs, there are maybe two Alien Grunts and Masters - the enemy variety could have been better from the gameplay aspect - the lack of stronger enemies really felt like the protagonist is away from the bigger happenings, making him feel like an underdog.
The gametime is about 3-4 hours, and the highs of it are the various little physics puzzles,  but other than that this game is everything but memorable.  We have less weapons than in the base game - Glock, Colt, machine gun, shotgun, rocket launcher, granade and satchel charge. (Plus Snarks, based on wiki) It's about the half of the arsenal we had in the base game or in Opposing Forces - this, with the short campaign makes this game nowhere as fun as the other titles were.

Well I have mixed feelings about this expansion but generally left satisfied. So pro-s and con-s
+ Xen. While I guess the best is yet to come (by Crowbar Collective in their "Black Mesa" or even official HL-3) for now IMHO here's the best Xen world for now. It's well desighned, interesting, have a good length for this game;
+ Lighting. What I noticed after original is that there's much better dark places. Just like in HL2: Episode 1 even with a flashlight you can't see everything and that's really add to the atmosphere;
+/- Challenging puzzles. just like original sometimes things aren't obvious.
+/- Weak AI
+/- Short
- Story doesn't feel important, The only good things are the beggining and small collaboration with scientist. All the other isn't interesting.
- While Xen is really good, for some reasons Black Mesa sometimes looks generic, blocky, plain etc.
- Dialogs and interaction with technics/people. They're not entertaining and take too much time and you just have to wait.
So while I can recommend this game, it's definately not "must have".

This game is really good, much better than Opposing Force. Gone are the stupid weapons and enemies and back are the really good ones from the original. The first half of the game the quality of the mapping is about the same as Opposing Force’s, but in the second half it does get a lot better. There is also a considerably better flow and story compared to Opposing Force, here there actually is one compared to the no existent one in Opposing Force.

There are no reused sections, although some did seem to take a lot of inspiration from Half-Life’s. However there is a heavy use of sections where you need to go a long way around just to open a door, this is done multiple times. Also not all the weapons are used, this is a good thing is some ways since everything in this game was not out of place, but there are still some non-energy\Xen weapons that are not used.

The main problem with the game is that is it too short, it really does feel like they made half the game, then ran out of time. This would explain the lake of weapons and also the lack of difficulty increase, there is no end boss and the end point does feel like a mid-point.

But this game is really good, if you had to choose between this and Opposing Force, choose this. Opposing Force was not that great, this however is really good, in some ways better than Half-Life.
